Graphical abstract Commonly applied in situ techniques and their applications on representative electrode materials are summarized, aiming at elucidating the composition/structure-performance relationship for electrochemical performance improvement to meet the global transition towards low-carbon energy. Energy storage is an ever-growing global concern due to increased energy needs and resource exhaustion. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have called increasing attention and achieved substantial progress in recent years owing to the abundance and even distribution of Na resources in the crust, and the predicted low cost of the technique. Nevertheless, SIBs still face challenges like lower energy density and inferior cycling stability compared to mature lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Enhancing the electrochemical performance of SIBs requires an in-deep and comprehensive understanding of the improvement strategies and the underlying reaction mechanism elucidated by in situ techniques. In this review, commonly applied in situ techniques, for instance, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), and their applications on the representative cathode and anode materials with selected samples are summarized. We discuss the merits and demerits of each type of material, strategies to enhance their electrochemical performance, and the applications of in situ characterizations of them during the de/sodiation process to reveal the underlying reaction mechanism for performance improvement. We aim to elucidate the composition/structure-performance relationship to provide guidelines for rational design and preparation of electrode materials toward high electrochemical performance. Keywords Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) In situ characterizations Electrode materials Composition/structure-performance 1 Introduction Modern society’s drastically increasing energy demands and resource depletion call for more efficient and sustainable energy storage techniques [1–5]. As a mature battery technique, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have achieved significant advancements in the past few decades, which reduce the dependence on fossil fuels [6–8]. Nevertheless, resources and cost issues associated with LIBs drive scientists to explore strategically potential alternatives for future energy [9–12]. Considering the similar physical and chemical properties with Li, the Na elemental abundance and even distribution and predicted low-cost sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have attracted much attention. They have been considered appealing alternatives to LIBs [13–15]. The primary motivation for exploring alternative batteries is to avoid the increasing cost related to the limited supply of Li due to its low elemental abundance and unevenly geographic distribution in the earth's crust, which is about 0.0065% in the form of various lithium-containing minerals, mainly distributed in Australia, Chile, China and Argentina [2,16–18]. In recent years, the increasing demand for lithium has skyrocketed its price. By contrast, sodium content in the earth's crust is about 2.74%, approximately-two to three orders of magnitude more abundant than lithium. Sodium is widely distributed on land and in the ocean [15–18]. The huge elemental abundance, lower price of sodium compared to lithium, and lower cost of Al foil than Cu foil show the appealing potential of SIBs for energy storage applications. However, compared with LIBs, SIBs have a lower energy density and inferior cycling performance due to the relatively heavier atomic mass (23 g mol−1 vs. 6.9 g mol−1) and higher standard electrode potential (2.71 V vs. 3.02 V vs. SHE) of Na compared to Li, which hinders the practical application of SIBs [4]. Therefore, great efforts have been made to explore cathode and anode materials with enhanced electrochemical performance in SIBs, including specific capacity, cycling stability, rate capability, output voltage, and energy density, which requires an in-deep and comprehensive understanding of strategies for performance improvement and the underlying reaction mechanism investigated by in situ techniques. Currently, the main catalogues of SIBs cathode materials are layered transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue analogues. The primary anode materials are insertion-type, conversion-type, and alloying-type materials. The main challenges of electrode materials are (1) Irreversible phase transitions or structure collapse during the de/sodiation process resulting in inferior capacity retention and cycling stability. (2) Sluggish ion diffusion kinetics due to poor electronic conductivity of materials and the large size of Na+ results in the limited rate capability. (3) Appropriate output voltage for cathode or anode materials determines the energy density of a full battery. Strategies like structure and morphology design, carbon coating or embedding, element doping or substitution, biphasic/bimetallic synergy, etc. can effectively suppress/reduce the phase transition, alleviate the strain stress, improve the electronic/ionic conductivity, and tune the output voltage of the electrode materials to improve their electrochemical performance. Elucidating the underlying reaction mechanism for electrochemical performance improvement requires in situ characterization techniques to track the de/sodiation process to provide real-time data for analysis. Various in situ techniques have been developed for studying the operation and degradation/failure mechanism of a running battery at an atomic or molecular level. They include microscopic techniques like scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), and scanning tunnel microscope (STM); X-ray techniques, such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), X-ray tomography, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS); spectroscopic techniques, such as Raman spectroscopy, Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), etc. Each technique has distinct principles and features that can provide specific information. Researchers can selectively employ-one technique or a combination of a few different techniques to obtain desired information. In this review, recent advances in the in situ characterizations of advanced electrode materials for SIBs toward high electrochemical performances are discussed and summarized using three representative cathode materials: layered transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue analogs, and three representative anode materials: insertion-type, conversion-type and alloying-type materials (Fig. 1 ) [14–18]. We first briefly introduce four commonly used in situ techniques for SIB studies, including TEM, Raman spectroscopy, XRD, and XANES. We introduced the principle, instrumentation, and the electrochemical cell for in situ measurements of each technique [19–30]. The recent advances in their applications on representative electrode materials are summarized with selected examples. We discuss the merits and demerits of each type of material, strategies to improve their battery performance, and their in situ characterizations during the de/sodiation process to reveal the underlying reaction mechanism for performance improvement. We aim to elucidate the composition/structure-performance relationship to provide guidelines for rational design and preparation of electrode materials toward high electrochemical performance. Last is the section of our summary and outlook on the future development of in situ characterization techniques on advanced SIBs. 2 Brief introduction on in situ TEM, Raman, XRD, and XANES To develop high-performance SIBs, it is necessary to monitor the evolution of morphology, structure, phase, and chemical state of electrode materials during the de/sodiation process from the atomic to the macro scale to have a deep understanding of its reaction mechanism. Traditional ex situ characterization techniques, such as SEM, TEM, XRD, NMR, etc., usually analyze the electrodes by disassembling the battery which has been charged or discharged to a specified state, which provides valuable information about the battery materials. However, this process is cumbersome and ignores electrode materials’ structure and state changes during battery disassembly, electrode extraction, and characterization. Therefore, the obtained experimental data have uncertainty and hysteresis. Modern in situ characterization techniques allow the characterization of batteries under realistic operating conditions, which is crucial for understanding the operation mechanism and degradation/failure mechanism for the rational design of electrodes toward high performance. Currently various in situ characterization techniques including in situ SEM, TEM, XRD, XPS, XANES, X-ray tomography, Raman spectroscopy, Infrared spectroscopy, NMR, etc. have been employed for studies of electrode materials. Each in situ characterization technique has a distinct principle and feature that can provide specific information for the desired purpose. The combination of different techniques can provide more complementary and comprehensive information. Herein the most commonly used in situ techniques for material studies, like TEM, Raman spectroscopy, XRD, and XANES are briefly introduced in principle, instrumentation, and the electrochemical cell for in situ measurements (Fig. 2 ) to facilitate the understanding of their application on mechanism studies of electrode materials for SIBs in the following sections. 2.1 In situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM is a technique that can realize physical morphology imaging and chemical state analysis by imposing a bias voltage to excite elastic or inelastic electrons by high-energy electron beam penetrating samples. It has many different working modes, such as high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), scanning TEM (STEM), selected electron diffraction, electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, etc. to realize real-time and dynamic monitoring of crucial information such as microstructure evolution, reaction kinetics, phase transition, chemical change and mechanical stress of electrodes at nano or even atomic level. For in situ TEM measurement, the samples should not be sucked out under the electromagnetic field and can remain stable in a high vacuum [31,32]. The instrumentation of TEM and the most commonly used in situ TEM cell for the studies of SIBs are shown in Fig. 2(a). The sample was transferred onto a TEM gold (Au) rod, or copper (Cu) grid acts as the working electrode, the fresh layer of sodium (Na) metal attached to a tungsten (W) probe acts as the counter electrode, and a natural sodium oxide layer of sodium oxide and sodium hydroxide on the surface of sodium metal acts as the solid-state electrolyte [24]. A potentiostat is applied to cycle the cell to obtain the probed electrode's dynamic physical and chemical information during cycling. In situ TEM is one of the most representative and vital techniques to systematically study the electrochemical reaction and failure mechanism of SIBs during charging and discharging. 2.2 In situ Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is based on the inelastic scattering of incident light interacting with substances. The frequency difference between the incident light and the scattered radiation is referredto as Raman shift, which corresponds to the vibrational energy levels of the molecule. A plot of the intensity of the scattered light as a function of Raman shifts formed a Raman spectrum, which is distinct and characteristic for both crystalline and amorphous molecules or crystals. Parameters such as the chemical/molecular structure, crystal symmetry, and strains caused by electrochemical stimulation can affect the vibrational modes of the molecules and crystals, which is the principle of in situ Raman spectroscopy for the studies of SIBs [25]. Typical Raman spectroscopy instrumentation and electrochemical cell used for in situ Raman measurement are illustrated in Fig. 2(b) [25–28]. The construction of the battery in the in situ Raman cell for investigation is in the glove box, which mimics the construction of coin cells. The counter electrode was firstly loaded at the spring-loaded piston, and after that was the separator, followed by the working electrode from bottom to top immersed in an electrolyte. A ∼1.0 mm diameter hole was drilled in the center of the current collector of the working electrode for the incident Raman laser illumination and the Raman signal collection from the back side of the electrode. The top lid then sealed the cell with an optical quartz window mounted on it. To make it air-tight, a rubber seal was used, enabling the in situ Raman investigation to perform conveniently in a normal atmosphere without vacuum conditions, which is one of the merits of this technique. 2.3 In situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) XRD is based on Bragg's law, in which a beam of X-rays passes through the specimen and is scattered by periodically arranged atoms in a crystal, yielding continuous diffraction patterns that generate information about the crystal structure, crystallite size, and strain of the crystal. The XRD device mainly includes reflection mode and transmission mode. Conventional laboratories usually use reflective devices, in which the incident X-ray and the signal collector are located on the same side of the battery (Fig. 2ci) [29]. The collected signals mainly come from the electrode surface exposed to X-rays and are relatively low. In transmission mode XRD, X-rays usually come from synchrotron radiation sources with extremely high intensity, which can directly penetrate the entire battery (Fig. 2cii), therefore significantly improving the signal acquisition speed and signal-to-noise ratio [33,34]. In situ XRD is a versatile technique to trace the structural variation, phase transitions, and lattice constant evolution of SIB electrodes during the charging/discharging process, which provides important data support for the operation and failure mechanism studies of SIBs. 2.4 In situ X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) X-ray absorption spectroscopy detects the local atomic and electronic structure around the absorbing atom. The XANES, spanning a region of 50–200 eV above the absorption edge, contains information about the type of ligand surrounding, composition, and oxidation state around the absorber. Instrumentation and electrochemical cell for in situ XANES measurement are illustrated in Fig. 2(d) [30]. A typical electrochemical in situ XANES cell comprises a Beryllium (Be) window for X-ray illumination and a Teflon O-ring behind it for sealing. The construction of the in situ cell mimics the construction of coin cells. In situ XANES based on a synchrotron radiation light source with high time resolution can be applied to investigate changes in oxidation state and fine structure of the cathode and anode materials for SIBs during cycling to reveal the reaction mechanism. Each in situ characterization technique has its characteristics, advantages, and limitations, which can be applied to trace the de/sodiation process of SIBs from different aspects at different levels. Currently, one or a combination of several complementary in situ characterization techniques are usually used as required to investigate the dynamic evolution of morphology, structural, phase, chemical states, or kinetics of the electrodes during the de/sodiation process to comprehensively elucidate the operation mechanism and degradation mechanism of SIBs for performance improvement. Their applications on cathode and anode materials for SIBs are summarized as follows. 3 In situ characterizations of cathode materials Cathode and anode are the core components of the SIBs, which significantly affect battery performance and occupy a considerable proportion of the cost of the battery. Therefore, they are the key parts of current research on SIBs and are mainly discussed here. Due to the similarities between SIBs and LIBs, the development of SIBs materials is often inspired by LIBs materials. Especially the cathode materials, the intercalation chemistry of both LIBs and SIBs is similar, making it possible to use similar compounds for both systems. Similar to LIBs, high-performance cathode materials for SIBs should be as follows: (1) high redox voltage upon the de/sodiation process to obtain high output voltage and energy density; (2) rapid Na+ de/intercalation kinetics to guarantee good rate capability; (3) low irreversible phase transitions during de/sodiation process to obtain a long cyclability. Currently, the most promising cathode materials for SIBs are layered transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue analogues. Their recent advances and in situ characterizations are summarized as follows. 3.1 Layered transition metal oxides The layered transition metal oxides (Na x TMO2, 0 < x ≤ 1, where T.M. stands for one or multiple transition metal elements such as Fe, Mn, Cu, Ni, V, etc., facilitating the redox reaction associated with Na+ de/intercalation) are appealing cathode materials in SIBs owing to their facile synthesis process, high specific capacity and ionic conductivity [35,36]. They are typically classified into two representative types, the O3-type and the P2-type based on the oxygen stacking sequence and the sodium ion coordination environment. In the O3-type phase, the oxygen stacking sequence is in ABCABC, and Na+ ions are in octahedral sites [37,38], while in the P2-type phase, the oxygen stacking is in ABBA and Na+ ions are in prismatic sites [39,40]. Apart from typical O3-type and P2-type, P3-type phase layered transition metal oxides characterized by oxygen stacking in ABBCCA with Na+ ion clamped between the TMO2 slabs through occupied capacious prismatic sites are used cathode materials for SIBs as well. Compared with the O3-type phase, the P2-type phase has a more open sodium ion transport channel and lower sodium ion diffusion barrier, showing better rate performance. However, they are only stable with sodium contents in the range of 0.3–0.7, resulting in lower capacities [41–45]. In contrast, the O3-type phase can achieve higher sodium contents in the range of 0.8 < x ≤ 1, releasing higher capacities. However, limited by the high energy barrier of adjacent octahedral sites, the sodium ion diffusion kinetics in the O3-type phase is sluggish, resulting in inferior rate capability [46–49]. Both the O3-type phase and P2-type phase commonly suffer from irreversible phase transitions during the de/sodiation process, which results in limited rate capability, capacity retention, and cycling stability. Composition and structure modulation [50–68], for instance, morphology design [54–58], surface coating [59–63], ion doping or substitution [37,40,41,43–49], and biphase synergy [50–53,68] are proved to suppress/reduce the irreversible phase transformation and improve the kinetics effectively, which lead to good chemical and dynamic stability and high sodium storage. Owing to the larger radius of Na+ compared to Li+, cathode materials of SIBs commonly suffer from sluggish kinetics. Rational morphology design is vital to improving Na+ kinetics, leading to improved rate capability [54–58]. Xiao et al. synthesized a P2-type Na2/3Ni1/6Mn2/3Cu1/9Mg1/18O2 (P2-NaNMCM) layered oxides, in which nanoflakes composed of a multiple-layer oriented stack (Fig. 3 a and b). Due to the optimized morphology modulation and element substitution, the cathode material displayed outstanding rate performance of 73% capacity retention at as high as 30 C compared to 0.5 C and remarkable cycling stability of 81.4% capacity retention after 500 cycles even at 5 C (Fig. 3c). In situ XRD was applied to monitor the evolution on structural of P2-NaNMCM during sodium ion extraction/insertion. It was found that the characteristic (002) and (004) peaks of the P2-NaNMCM moved toward a lower angle while the (100) and (102) peaks moved toward a higher angle, which indicated the contraction of the ab-plane by c-axis expanding. All the XRD peaks experienced a completely reversible recovery and finally recovered to their initial states after a full cycle, which accounted for the excellent cycling stability due to the refrain of the Jahn-Teller distortion by Mg2+ (Fig. 3d). Moreover, the incorporation of copper from Cu2+/Cu3+ redox coupled into the transition metal layer contributed to the improved kinetic properties of the electrode material [56]. Liu etal. have successfully produced O3-type NaNi0.5Mn0.5O2 hollow microbars with {010} facets through an ethanol-mediated co-precipitation synthesis method with large-scale industrial feasibility. After long-term cycling, the cathode material showed appealing rate capability and ultra-long cycling life with structure and morphology stability [57]. Li et al. synthesized pure monocrystal Na0.44MnO2 nanoplate by the template-assisted sol–gel method. The material exhibited better electrochemical performance than other previously reported Na0.44MnO2 compounds owing to well-distributed channels, controlled morphology, and negligible phase transformation for fast and stable sodium ions diffusion during the de/sodiation process demonstrated by in situ XRD characterization [58]. Surface coating can efficiently minimize the unexpected phase transition and become the buffer layer to alleviate the stress and strain, hence improving the cycling life [59–63]. Carbon coating is the most conventionally used surface coating technology to improve the conductivity of the electrode materials and relieve the stress and strain during battery cycling. Xia et al. reported the application of in situ XRD to monitor the solvothermal reaction process, which showed the α-Fe2O3 (R-3C) to γ-Fe2O3 (Fd-3m) to α-NaFeO2 (R-3m) product formation (Fig. 3e and f). A ∼5 nm thin layer of carbon was coated on O3-NaFeO2 nanoflakes, which enhanced its electrode kinetics and structural stability leading to enhanced rate performance and cycling life not only in a half-cell test but also in a full cell (NaFeO2@C//hard carbon) test as shown in Fig. 3(g) [61]. Chemical element doping or substitution is crucial in suppressing phase transitions and maintaining the stability of the materials to improve the electrochemistry properties of transition layered metal oxides for SIBs. Hu and co-workers reported an O3-type NaNi0.12Cu0.12Mg0.12Fe0.15Co0.15Mn0.1Ti0.1Sn0.1Sb0.04O2 layered oxide cathode material. It exhibited highly reversible O3-P3 phase transitions with higher than 60% of the overall specific capacity accommodated in the O3-type domain. The authors revealed the novel concept of high-entropy reaction, in which the entropy was stabilized on the host matrix to maintain the O3-type structure, which guaranteed good rate capability and long cycle life. In situ XRD revealed the accommodation of the change of local interactions during sodium ion de/interaction due to the high-entropy stabilization on the host matrix of multiple transition-metal components [37]. In 2022, Guo’s group synthesized a P2-Na0.7Li0.03Mg0.03Ni0.27Mn0.6Ti0.07O2 (P2-NaLMNMT) due to the synergetic effect of evaluated multiple ions, the electrode showed superior battery performance with reversible specific capacity of 134 mA h g−1, 82% of the capacity retention after 200 cycles (Fig. 4 a), and rate capability of 4 C with 110 mA h g−1. In situ XANES revealed the capacity contribution from the Ni2+/Ni4+ redox couple, while Mn ions do not involve in the redox reaction (Fig. 4b and c). Co-substitution of Li+ to suppress Na-vacancy ordering, Ti4+ to increase redox potential, and Mg2+ to stabilize structure are also demonstrated. In situ XRD revealed that the Li+, Ti4+, and Mg2+ converted the unstable and huge volume P2-O2 phase transition into a moderate P2-Z phase transition during the de/sodiation process, which increased the energy barrier of transition metal slabs gliding, therefore alleviate the large-volume phase transition (Fig. 4d–g) [43]. In 2021, Li’s group explored the underlying mechanism of electrochemical performance improvement of Titanium (Ti) substitution in P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (P2-NaNM) to form P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn1/3Ti1/3O2 (P2–NaNMT) (Fig. 5 a–c) by in situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 5d and e). They found that for both P2-NaNM and P2-NaNMT, the appearance of the distinct Raman band at 524 cm−1 and its shifting to 539 cm−1 indicated the oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+ to Ni4+ during desodiation. For P2-NaNM, upon charging to higher than 4.1 V, the distinct A1g band at 592 cm−1 moved to 585 cm−1, which was attributed to the attenuation of the force between the Na layer and the transition metal layer during the release of Na+, leading to the expansion of the transition metal layer and the shifting of the A1g peak to lower wavelength. During the de/sodiation, a phase transition from P2 to O2 was observed in P2-NaNM, while there was a relatively gentle phase change in P2-NaNMT due to the Ti substitution. The P2-NaNMT showed better cycling performance than P2-NaNM [27]. The biphasic synergy of P2-O3, P2-P3, and other phases has attracted much attention recently, which integrates the advantages of multiple crystalline phases in layered transition metal oxide materials to achieve performance improvement. Simultaneously, the investigation and the understanding of synergetic materials can inspire a novel research field to explore the best features of each phase and the merits of multiphase integration. Wang and co-workers have explored a novel P2/O3 layered biphasic material, Na0.76Ni0.33Mn0.5Fe0.1Ti0.07O2 (Com-NaNMFT) through a reasonable biphasic tailoring method. Due to the reversible phase transformation within transition metal oxide and the reduced stress at the boundary of the two phases of the integrated material during sodium ion de/insertion, the Com-NaNMFT biphasic composite showed dramatically improved battery performance as a cathode for SIBs, which included high reversible specific capacity of 144 mA h g−1, remarkable rate capability of 92 mA h g−1 cycled at 10 C, and good cycling stability of 81.5% of capacity maintain after 100 cycles at a rate of 0.2 C. It showed apparent advantages compared to its single-phase counterparts P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn0.57Ti0.1O2 (NaNMT) and (O3-NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 (NaNFM). In situ XRD revealed a completely reversible phase evolution of P2/O3-P2/O3/P3-P2/P3-P2/Z/O3′-Z/O3′ according to the Ni2+/Ni3.5+, Fe3+/Fe4+ and Mn3.8+/Mn4+ redox reactions (exposed by XANES and corresponding EXAFS shown in Fig. 6 a–d) during sequential sodium ions de/insertion [50]. Guo et al. have presented a layered integrated cathode with P2-P3 biphasic structures, Na0.7Li0.06Mg0.06Ni0.22Mn0.67O2. Benefiting from the respective merits of P2 and P3 phases and highly reversible P2/P3-P2/OP4 phase transition elucidated by in situ XRD, the material delivered a capacity of 119 mA h g−1 according to Ni2+/Ni4+ redox reaction revealed by in situ XANES, and appealing rate performance of 5 C with 85.5% of capacity retention [52]. Zhou’s group reported a P2-type Na0.66Li0.22Ru0.78O2 layered oxide cathode material for SIBs, which exhibited superior reversible capacity cycled in the potential range from 1.5 V to 4.5 V with an almost negligible capacity drop of 0.018% during cycles. The underlying mechanism of the outstanding cyclability was investigated by XANES, EXAFS, in situ SHINERS, bulk Raman, and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) (Fig. 6e), which revealed the O2−/O2 n − and Ru4+/Ru5+ combined cationic and anionic redox reactions contributing to the superior capacity during the de/sodiation. The combination of strong Ru-O covalency and stable Li-O-Na bond contributed to cycling stability [40]. 3.2 Polyanionic compounds Polyanionic compounds (Na x TM y (XO4) n , where T.M. = transition metals and X = P, S, Si, Se, etc.) are considered one of the most fascinating cathode materials owing to their superior cycling stability, remarkable rate capability, and high thermodynamic stability. The inductive effect of polyanions in the structure stabilizes the energy of the redox couple, making it possible to operate at high voltages (as high as 4 V vs. Na+/Na) to obtain relatively high energy densities. The robust 3D framework decreases the structural variation, and the effect of strong X-O covalent bonds inhibits oxygen evolution, which provides long-term structural stability, leading to long cycle life and high safety. However, low ionic and electronic conductivity and limited capacity due to the heavier molar mass restrict their further application [8,9,69,70]. Different strategies have been developed to relieve the influences of these shortcomings, for instance, carbon coating [71–75], introducing dopant elements [76–82], and mixing more electronegative anion systems with F, N, O, etc. [83–86]. These strategies increase intrinsic and extrinsic conductivity of the material, enhance sodium ions diffusion, and modulate redox voltage of materials, which provide more structural diversity and synergistically enhance the battery performance of the materials (Fig. 7 ). There are various polyanion materials for SIBs, including phosphates, fluorophosphates, pyrophosphates, mixed phosphates, sulfates, and silicates. Among them, sodium superionic conductor (NASICON)-type Na3V2(PO4)3 and its derivatives are regarded as the most appealing ones owning to their advantages of stable structure and high redox potential, hence are representatively discussed here [8,9,69,70]. The theoretical energy density of Na3V2(PO4)3 is 400 Wh kg−1, and it was proved to possess good thermal stability under charged state at 450 °C, enabling safe battery operation. Xu and co-workers synthesized carbon-coated hierarchical NaTi2(PO4)3 mesoporous micro-flowers, which have an appealing electrochemical performance of excellent high-rate capability of 95 mA h g−1 at a rate of 100 C and ultra-long cycling life of 77.3% of capacity retention after cycled for 10,000 times at a rate of 20 C. In situ XRD clarified a typical two-phase reaction of NaTi2(PO4)3 electrode with reversible structure change [77]. Chen et al. doped Cr into Na3V2(PO4)3 to form Na3V1.5Cr0.5(PO4)3. In situ XANES investigation and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that the Cr doping activated the V4+/V5+ redox couple and lowered sodium diffusion barriers, dramatically improving energy density and cycling stability. The cathode material exhibited a high specific capacity of 163.2 mA h g−1 at a rate of 0.1 C and a good cyclability and rate capability of 72.1% of capacity retention after cycled 2650 times at a rate of 5 C [80]. Increasing the capacity and output voltage of polyanionic materials is desired to further increase their energy density. Since it is challenging to increase their capacity because of their heavy molecular mass, increasing the output voltage is the other option. Introducing anions with high electronegativity into a polyanionic material is proven to be a rational strategy to increase the redox potential by virtue of the inductive effect. F−, N3 −, O2 2−, etc. with high electronegativity enable the weakening of the covalent bond between metal and oxygen, which leads to a more significant energy difference between antibonding orbitals and vacuum, thus leading to higher redox potential. Dou’s group prepared an N-doped graphene oxide-wrapped Na3V(PO3)3N material with a homogeneous carbon coating layer. Due to the carbon coating and N doping, the material possessed a 4 V-class redox potential, a capacity of 78.9 mA h g−1 at a rate of 0.1 C, 75.9% of the retained capacity at a rate of 10 C within 5000 cycles (Fig. 8 a). In situ XANES (Fig. 8b) and EELS results revealed the V3.2+/V4.2+ redox couple while N was not involved in the electrochemical reactions. In situ XRD observations showed zero strain during phase transition (Fig. 8c) [82]. Tarascon’s group developed Na3V2(PO4)2F3/C, which was capable of triggering the third sodium through the formation of a disordered NaxV2(PO4)2F3 phase of tetragonal symmetry from 1.0 V to 4.8 V with average V oxidation state changing from 3 to 4.5, resulting in 10–20% increase in the energy density demonstrated by in situ XRD and XANES [83]. Ceder’s group showed the sodium insertion into Na3V2(PO4)2FO2 at 1.57 V to form Na4V2(PO4)2F3 revealed by in situ XRD with high energy density, long-term cycle life, and outstanding high-rate capabilities [86]. 3.3 Prussian blue analogs Prussian blue analogs (P.B.A.s, Na2M A [M .B. (C.N.)6].xH2O, where M = Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, Cu, etc.) are hexacyanoferrates. They own an open and rigid 3D framework structure with plenty of redox-active centers, leading to good rate capability, cycling stability, and high specific capacity. The two-electron redox reaction also allows a large capacity, and the simple and non-toxic synthetic route can effectively reduce the production cost of P.B.A.s [87–90]. The main problem of P.B.A.s is that Fe (C.N.)6 vacancies and lattice water molecules will reduce the Na content in the lattice. At the same time, some water molecules will be extracted into the electrolyte, resulting in a decrease in the first cycle efficiency and cycle performance [91–93]. Morphology engineering [94–98], surface modification [99–102], enhancing the crystallinity [103,104], transition metal (TM) doping or elemental substitution [105–108], and high-entropy [109] are the common strategies developed to solve these problems. Wan et al. synthesized a hollow Prussian blue nano-frames/carbon nanotubes composite film, FeHCFe nano-frames/NTs, in which the FeHCFe nano-frames were fully surrounded by CNTs, significantly enhancing the electronic conductivity of the cathode. Due to the dual strategy design, the material provided enhanced tolerance for lattice expansion when it underwent a two-electron redox reaction during de/sodiation: cubic FeIIIFeIII(C.N.)6 (Prussian yellow) ↔ cubic NaFeIIIFeII(C.N.)6 (Prussian blue) ↔ rhombohedral Na2FeIIFeII(C.N.)6 revealed by in situ XRD. It, therefore, delivered a specific capacity of 149.2 mA h g−1 at a rate of 0.1 C and retained 92% of capacity after 500 cycles at a rate of 5 C [94]. The hollow structure with large buffer space and surface-active sites can effectively release volume expansion and accelerate ion transfer rate, resulting in high specific capacity, good cycling, and rate performance. Ren et al. synthesized (Na3.1Fe4[Fe(C.N.)6]3) hierarchical nanotubes, which had completely open configurations and rendered fast sodium ions de/intercalation. In situ Raman spectroscopy and XRD analysis verified that the pseudo-capacitance effect facilitated full reaction of N-FeIII/FeII sites with an extremely small volume expansion of <2.1%. The cathode delivered a capacity of 83 mA h g−1 at a rate of 50 C and an ultra-stable cyclability of cycled over 10,000 times for sodium storage (Fig. 9 a–c) [98]. Liu et al. reported polydopamine (PDA) coated nano cubic porous Na x FeFe(N)6. Due to the coupling between the Na x FeFe(CN)6 active material and the PDA coating, the electrode exhibited a capacity of 72.6 mA h g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 and 93.8 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.2 A g−1. In situ electrochemical Raman spectroscopy and theoretical simulations revealed that FeII sites in PB enable coupling with the PDA outer layer to keep the P.B. structure stable. Furthermore, the Na+ extraction/insertion of the PB structure was improved after PDA coating, which improved the sodium storage properties, Fig. 9(d–f) [100]. Wang et al. reported the MnHCF@PEDOT composites prepared through co-precipitation followed by a facile in situ polymerization method [101]. Zhang et al. reported the PVP-assisted surface engineering to reconcile the Prussian blue surface with the PANI layer and finally synthesized core–shell PB@PANI nanocubes at low temperatures [102]. These morphology engineering and surface modification methods enabled PBAs to offer enhanced tolerance for lattice expansion, shorten Na+ diffusion path, improve electronic conductivity and optimize redox reactions, bringing a high specific capacity, outstanding rate capability, and long cycle life for SIBs. Enhancing the crystallinity during materials synthesis can effectively reduce the vacancies and lattice water molecules, thus leading to improved cycling stability of PBAs. Xie et al. synthesized Mn, Co, Ni-co-doped PBA by a modified co-precipitation method, in which a chelating agent of sodium citrate was used to control the crystallization rate to achieve high purity and crystallinity product with fewer vacancies and coordinated H2O in the lattice. The obtained MnCoNi-PBA exhibited stable cubic-rhombohedral phase transition during cycling elucidated by in situ XRD, which helped improve the cycling stability, showing the capacity retention of 81.1% after 500 cycles [104]. Dou’s group synthesized sodium-rich Na1.73FeFe(CN)6·3.8H2O with a highly reversible rhombohedral structure, which is easy to scale up. Owing to its stable structure, the cathode material showed excellent battery performance of 70 mA h g−1 discharge capacity at a specific current of 2.0 A g−1 and 71% retained capacity after 500 cycles. Synchrotron in situ PXRD revealed the highly reversible structure of rhombohedral during sodium-ion de/insertions with the three-phase transformation between rhombohedral, cubic, and tetragonal with negligible volume variation. The authors further demonstrated the practical application of rhombohedral Na2 −x FeFe(C.N.)6 by conducting a scale-up precipitation experiment and fabricating a pouch full cell with a cycle life of over 1000 times, Fig. 9(g–k) [105]. For the PPBAs cathode, recently reported research about high-entropy P.B.A. attracts a lot of interest, which employed in situ XRD measurements successfully found the effect of entropy-mediated suppression of phase transitions. By introducing various different elements into a one-phase structure, multicomponent materials were generated with high configurational entropy, which leads to many possible combinations of interactions, thus suppressing the phase transitions during de/sodiation. As shown in Fig. 10 (a–f), during the first two dis/charge cycles, high-entropy-Mn-based hexacyanoferrate, Na x Mn0.4Fe0.15Ni0.15Cu0.15Co0.15[Fe(C.N.)6] (HEM-HCF, 40% Mn) showed no phase transition, medium-entropy HCF (MEM-HCF, 80% Mn) showed a reversible phase transition from cubic to tetragonal. In contrast, the low-entropy HCF (LEM-HCF, 60% Mn) showed irreversible cubic to a tetragonal phase transition. The increasing entropy suppressed the structural degradation and phase transitions, leading to the improvement of the cycling performance of the HEM-HCF material [109]. 4 In situ characterizations of anode materials There are three main types of anode materials for rechargeable SIBs based on the reaction mechanism during the de/sodiation process: insertion-type, conversion-type, and alloying-type materials. The corresponding representative materials are carbonaceous, titanium-based oxides, CeO2, Nb2O5, metal oxides/sulfides, and metal alloys. 4.1 Insertion anode materials The most important insertion anode materials are carbonaceous materials like hard carbon, soft carbon, expanded graphite, graphene, carbon nanofibers, carbon nanotubes, etc., which have been intensively investigated for sodium ions storage [110–126]. They are widely accepted due to their capability to store sodium ions into their structure with a reasonable reversible specific capacity of about 300 mA h g−1 at a low operating voltage of about 0 V vs. Na+/Na. The sodium storage performance of carbonaceous materials can be further enhanced by pore control [116–118], interlayer spacing control [123], and heteroatom (such as N, S, and P) doping [119,125], and the underlying sodium storage mechanism have been investigated by in situ XRD [117], TEM [120–122], and Raman spectroscopy [123–126], etc. Liu et al. conducted in situ TEM to investigate the de/sodiation behavior of individual hollow carbon nanofibers (CNFs) consisting of a bilayer wall with an inner layer of crystalline-carbon (c-C) surrounded by an outer layer of disordered-carbon (d-C) with a Na+ accommodation capacity of 245 mA h g−1. The d-C exhibited ∼3 times volume expansion compared to the c-C after fully sodiated, which suggested a much higher sodium ion storage capability of the former than the latter. Moreover, the formation of longitudinal cracks at the boundary of d-C and c-C was observed and attributed to the anisotropic sodiation strains between them, which revealed the mechanical degradation of C.N.F.s [120]. The de/sodiation process of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) was investigated by in situ TEM as well. The growth of the solid electrolyte interface layer and sodium dendrites were observed on the surface of the sodiated MWCNTs shown in Fig. 11 (a–h). The pristine MWCNTs showed perfect mechanical flexibility, while the sodiated MWCNTs were fragile and broke easily (Fig. 11i–n) [121]. Wan et al. observed the reversible formation of Na metal cluster and irreversible formation of sodium oxide on the rGO anode surface by in situ TEM, which explained the high capacity of 450 mA h g−1 and revealed the reason for the capacity attenuation of rGO in the initial cycle [122]. These in situ TEM studies on carbonaceous materials elucidated the reaction mechanism, evolution structure, and mechanical degradation of carbonaceous anodes during the de/sodiaiton, which provided guidelines for the exploration of high-performance carbonaceous anodes for SIBs. Raman spectroscopy has become one of the most important techniques for the characterization of carbonaceous materials to determine their types and quality and the effects of perturbations, such as strain, doping, intercalation, and degree of disorder. Mai’s group synthesized kinds of hard carbon nanofibers (HCNFs) with adjustable interlayer spacings of over 0.40 nm (HCNF-1200), 0.37–0.34 nm (HCNF-1400), and 0.34 nm (HCNF-1600) by tuning the carbonization temperature from 1200 to 1600 °C to investigate the sodium ion storage mechanisms. The HCNF-1400 delivered a better reversible capacity (388 mA h g−1) and rate performance than HCNF-1200 and HCNF-1600 due to its optimized feature of a short-range graphitic layer with enough interlayer spacing for sodium ion intercalation. In situ Raman revealed that during discharging in the slope region, the intercalation of Na+ into the interlayers of graphic carbon resulted in the splitting of the G-band into two bands and shifting to lower wavenumbers at the plateau region. The pore filling of Na+ led to the unchanging of the G-band. The intensity of the D-band decreased during discharging, which was attributed to the adsorption of Na+ on the surfaces defects of the electrode material (Fig. 12 a). The adsorption/intercalation-filling Na+ storage mechanism of HCNFs (Fig. 12b) was further verified by in situ XRD showing the narrowing and intensity decreasing of the (002) diffraction in the slope region while no apparent changing of that in the plateau region (Fig. 12c) [123]. In situ Raman was applied to investigate the Na+ storage mechanism of hierarchically pyridinic-nitrogen enriched porous carbon (N-HPC), whose discharge–charge profiles showed only the slope region. Correspondingly, only adsorption-intercalation behavior was observed on the in situ Raman spectra by presenting the redshift of the G band during the complete discharging process. The N-HPC delivered a capacity of 149 mA h g−1 after 2,000 cycles with only 0.0081% capacity loss per cycle and a high-rate capability of 92 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1 [123]. Graphite owning well arranged layered structure and superior electrical conductivity is the conventional anode for commercial LIBs. However, it is inert to sodium ion insertion. Using linear ether-based electrolytes, Zhu et al. realized the unprecedented Na+ storage into graphite with acceptable capacity (∼110 mA h g−1), long cycling stability (∼6000 cycles), and high rate capability (10 A g−1). In situ Raman spectroscopy and CV revealed the intercalation of solvated-Na into graphene layers and the intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior for graphite's outstanding sodium ion storage performance [124]. Similarly, benefiting from the co-intercalation of the diglyme solvent and the Na+ into crystalline few-layer graphene (FLG), in which the diglyme solvent shell encapsulated the Na+ core to act as a “nonstick ion” to facilitate rapid ion de/insertion, the FLG anode for SIBs yielded great electrochemical performance. It exhibited a specific capacity above 150 mA h g−1, cycling stability with a slight capacity loss over 8000 cycles, and ∼120 mA h g−1 capacity maintained at a specific current of 12 A g−1 (∼30 s charge), as shown in Fig. 12(d). In situ Raman clarified the sodium ion staging sequence and isolated Fermi energies for the 1st and 2nd stage ternary intercalation compounds at ∼0.8 eV and ∼1.2 eV (Fig. 12e and f) [126]. Apart from carbonaceous materials, TiO2 [127,128], CeO2 [129], Nb2O5 [130] etc. are important insertion-type anode materials as well. Passerini’s group applied in situ XRD, ex situ XPS, SEM, and Raman spectroscopy to investigate the mechanism of Na+ insertion in anatase TiO2 nanoparticles. Based on these investigations, they proposed a new reaction mechanism, in which the sodium titanate phase was formed initially, which then disproportionated into another sodium titanate phase, Ti, NaO2, and O2. The newly formed sodium titanate phase reversibly provided a capacity of 140 mA h g−1 while the rests are irreversible [128]. This group also doped Fe into CeO2 to form Ce0.9Fe0.1O2− δ . The latter showed about a 100% capacity increase compared to the former as an insertion-type anode for SIBs in both half-cell and full-cell. A complementary combination of in situ XRD and DFT calculation revealed that the additional available space and the selective reduction of the Fe dopant contribute to the improved capacity and cyclability [129]. Orthogonal-phase niobium oxide (T-Nb2O5) is an appealing anode material for SIBs due to its high theoretical capacity (200 mA h g−1) and high ionic diffusion coefficient. The sodium behaviors along the (001) lattice planes and the [001] direction of the T-Nb2O5 nanosheet were investigated by in situ TEM, and lots of dislocations and domain boundaries were observed, which allowed the diffusion of Na+ across the (001) lattice planes through them rapidly. The material showed good rate capability [130]. 4.2 Conversion-type and alloying-type anode materials Because of the limited specific capacity of the current mainstream insertion carbon-based SIBs anode materials, high reversible capacity anode materials based on conversion and alloying reactions have been explored. The anode materials based on conversion reactions are accompanied by breaking old chemical bonds and forming new chemical bonds during the de/sodiation process. In general, the equation for the conversion reaction can be defined as TM a X b + (b*c) Na+ + (b*c)e− → aTM + bNa c X, where TM represents transition metals such as Fe, Ni, Mn, etc., and X represents anionic species (O, S, P, F, etc.) [131–135,140–144,146–151]. Compared with traditional insertion materials, the conversion-type anode materials exhibit a higher theoretical capacity (2–3 times) due to the multi-electron transfer reaction [140–144]. Theoretical calculations show that some group 14 and 15 elements (Sn, Sb, Bi, Si, Ge, and P) and their compounds can store a large number of Na+ in the host structure through an alloying reaction with a relatively low operating potential (<1.0 V), providing high capacity [136–139,145,152–154]. However, both conversion-type and alloy-type anode materials face two challenging issues. First, severe volume variation in the bulk material during repeated de/sodiation process owing to a large number of sodium ions reacting with host materials and large size of Na+, which causes the aggregation and pulverization of active materials and leads to rapid capacity decay of these materials. Second, sluggish ion diffusion kinetics due to poor electronic conductivity of the bulk material and the large size of Na+ [146–151]. Strategies to overcome these issues to achieve improved electrochemical performance include: (i) downsizing the materials to nano-scale and embedding them in the carbon shells or matrices to shorten the Na+ diffusion pathways, lower the mechanical stress accompanying the conversion/alloying reactions, and increase the electronic conductivity of the materials, thus alleviating the pulverization and sluggish ion diffusion kinetics issues. (ii) Introducing a second or third element into the host material to take advantage of the synergetic effect of different elements to realize higher electronic conductivity and richer redox chemistry of the materials [152–156]. MnS (∼50 nm) were enclosed in N, S co-doped carbon shell to form MnS@NSC core–shell nanocubes, which showed a high reversible specific capacity of 594.2 mA h g−1 at a specific current of 0.1 A g−1, outstanding cycling stability of a capacity attenuation rate of 0.0068% per cycle in 3000 cycles, and an excellent rate capability. SAED patterns of MnS@NSC at a series of sodiation times showed the conversion reaction of MnS to Mn and Na2S with two electron transfers (Fig. 13 a–f), which contributed to the high capacity. In situ TEM showed the confinement effect of the carbon shell on the MnS core during successive de/sodiation processes to maintain the integrity of MnS@NSC. Further investigation on the de/sodiation process of MnS@NSC by in situ Raman spectroscopy showed the Raman peak at 654 cm−1 assigned to the MnSC bond vibration (Fig. 9g and h), which was crucial in connecting the MnS core and the carbon shell. Both the confinement and connecting effects contributed to the improved cycling stability of the MnS@NSC compared to MnS illustrated in Fig. 13i and j) [134]. In situ TEM was applied to probe the structural and phase evolution of conversion-type electrode material of NiCo2O4, which converted to NiO and CoO metal oxides first and then further converted to Ni and Co nanograins embedded in Na2O matrix in the first sodiation. In the following first desodiation, the Ni and Co converted to metal oxides NiO and CoO rather than the original bimetallic oxide NiCo2O4, which is different from the conversion reaction between the NiCo2O4 and Li and could be used to explain the inferior battery performance in SIBs than in LIBs since the second de/sodiation, a stable and reversible phase transformation was built between CoO/NiO and Co/Ni during the following cycles [135]. Alloying type anode Bi@Void@C yolk-shell structure has been rationally designed and applied as an anode for SIBs. Volume expansion of the Bi was observed during the sodiation process by in situ TEM, which was effectively accommodated by the void space between the Bi yolk and the carbon shell. The Bi@Void@C, therefore maintained the integrity of the yolk-shell structure during the first cycle (Fig. 14 a) and the successive de/sodiation (Fig. 14b). In situ XRD revealed a two-phase reaction of Bi/NaBi and NaBi/Na3Bi during sodiation and the reversed process during the desodiation (Fig. 14c). The optimized yolk-shell structure of Bi@Void@C allowed the material unprecedented rate performance of 173 mA h g−1 at a specific current of 0.1 A g−1 and extraordinary cycling life of delivering a capacity of 198 mA h g−1 after 10 000 cycles at 20 A g−1, which was better than other reported Bi-based materials for SIBs [139]. Lin et al. synthesized a nitrogen-doped porous carbon-coated nickel cobalt bimetallic sulfide hollow nanocube ((Ni0.5Co0.5)9S8@NC) composite via a hydrothermal method and subsequent pyrolysis (Fig. 15 a). Because of the unique hollow nano-structure, the nanocomposite displayed an outstanding specific capacity of 752 mA h g−1 at a specific current of 0. 1 A g−1 after 100 cycles and a remarkable rate capability of 700 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1, 680 mA h g−1 at 2.0 A g−1 for sodium storage (a 97% capacity retention for a twofold increase in high specific currents, Fig. 15b). The pseudocapacitive effect contributes to the Na+ storage. In situ XRD revealed the conversion reaction mechanism of the electrode, which formed metallic Ni, Co, and Na2S and Na2S5 sulfides (Fig. 15c) [150]. Sun et al. presented the appealing anodic performance of the passionfruit-like Cu2ZnSnS4 nanoparticles confined within nitrogen-doped carbon (CZTS@C) for SIBs, which delivered a reversible capacity of 461 mA h g−1 at a specific current of 0.05 A g−1 after 140 cycles and outstanding cycling stability of a capacity of 146 mA h g−1 at a specific current of 4.0 A g−1 even after 1000 cycles. Such superior performance originated from multiple electrons involved in the conversion and alloying reactions of the CZTS@C composite revealed by in situ XRD investigations [151]. Sn anode for SIBs enabled a high reversible capacity of ∼800 mA h g−1 using glyme-based electrolytes. In situ XRD and ex-situ XPS elucidated the Na x Sn (x< 1)-NaSn-Na9Sn4-Na15Sn4 multiple alloying reactions during the sodiation and the Na15Sn4-Na9Sn4-NaSn-Na reversible dealloying reaction during the desodiation as shown in Fig. 16 (a–c) [152]. 5 Summary and outlook We have summarized recent advances in the in situ characterizations of advanced electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries toward high electrochemical performances. In situ characterizations of cathode materials of layered transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, Prussian blue analogs, and anode materials of insertion-type, conversion-type, and alloying-type materials with selected examples are discussed. We discuss the merits and demerits of each type of material, strategies to improve their electrochemical performance, and the in situ investigations of them by TEM, Raman spectroscopy, XRD, and XANES during the de/sodiation process to reveal the underlying reaction mechanism for performance improvement. Through in-deep and comprehensive discussion, it was found that the challenges of irreversible phase transitions or structure collapse, sluggish ion diffusion kinetics, and output voltage of electrode materials during successive de/sodiation process can be alleviated by composition and structure modulation, for instance, morphology design, carbon coating or embedding, element doping or substitution, and biphasic/bimetallic synergy, etc. The underlying mechanism is to suppress/reduce the phase transition, alleviate the strain stress, improve the electronic/ionic conductivity, and tune the output voltage of the electrode materials by composition and structure modulation to improve their specific capacity, cycling life, rate capability, and energy density. Beyond the mainstream inorganic electrode materials, organic electrode materials usually contain four natural and abundant elements, C, H, O, and N. They can be directly achieved from renewable organic molecule resources or their derivatives or selectively synthesized through green methods, which reduce energy consumption and carbon dioxide release during the material processing. Compared to traditional inorganic materials, organic electroactive materials show the advantages of resource sustainability, environmental friendliness, easy end-of-life treatment, and low cost. As the molecular structure and multi-electron redox centers of the organic electrode materials can be designed and processed, the organic electrode materials have distinct advantages over inorganic electrode materials in structure diversity, flexibility, and processability. These merits of organic electrode materials show their appealing potential for large-scale SIB application. However, their practical applications have not been realized at present due to their low electronic conductivity, dissolution in an electrolyte, and uncertain redox reaction mechanism. Applying in situ techniques, especially spectroscopic techniques such as Raman and IR, to track the redox reaction process of organic electrode materials to clarify the underlying mechanism to solve the problems mentioned above would be an essential research direction in the future [157]. Although great effort has been made to develop advanced cathode and anode materials for SIBs and great progress has been achieved in the past few decades, it is worth noting that the improvement of the overall electrochemical performance of a battery depends on the combined effect of electrodes and electrode/electrolyte interface. A dense and stable electrode/electrolyte interface is vital for SIBs to operate over decades. Continuous solid electrolyte interface (SEI) and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) growth and degradation consume the electrolyte, increase the cell impedance, and lower the columbic efficiencies, which can detrimentally affect the battery’s capacity retention, rate capability, and life span. However, the studies on the interface are even more challenging than on electrode materials due to the complexity of the interfacial environment and the weak signal of the generated interfacial species [158]. Surface sensitive in situ techniques, such as XPS, FTIR, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS), AFM, and STM, are promising techniques for investigating the interface. Each in situ characterization technique has its characteristics, advantages, and limitations. In general, in situ TEM applies a high-energy electron beam to penetrate ultra-thin samples to generate a series of elastic and inelastic electronic signals, which can accurately characterize the internal crystal structure and chemical state of the battery with atomic spatial resolution, millisecond time resolution, and 1 eV energy resolution (EELS). However, the preparation of the corresponding nano-scale samples is complex. The continuous high-energy electron beam irradiation may also affect the electrochemical reaction process of the nano-scale battery, making the experimental data deviate from the actual battery performance. In situ X-ray technology has a strong penetration ability to batteries. It can be performed on reflection (conventional XRD) or transmission (XRD and XANES based on synchrotron radiation) mode on batteries to obtain the phase (XRD), composition, and chemical state (XANES) information of the batteries. However, XRD can only obtain a signal from crystalline samples, which is invalid for amorphous samples. Raman spectroscopy is based on the inelastic scattering of the incident laser interaction with samples and can obtain a signal from both crystalline and amorphous samples. Nevertheless, the Raman signal is weak, and certain enhancement effects should be taken advantage of during measuring. Therefore, on the one hand, continuous effort should be made to improve the time resolution, energy resolution, and spatial resolution of various in situ characterization techniques to overcome their limitations. On the other hand, combining several in situ characterization techniques to obtain more comprehensive and systematic information on the running battery is the development tendency for future battery research. The advanced high electrochemical performance SIBs could be eventually achieved through a thorough operation mechanism and degradation mechanism of running batteries via in situ characterizations. In situ characterizations are vital in elucidating the underlying reaction mechanism of SIBs during cycling. However, they are mainly performed on lab-scale batteries. Monitoring the state of batteries on a practical scale during a realistic running situation, for instance, the temperature, gas evolution, degradation, etc., to identify battery faults for repair in time or to establish the health record of the battery for early warning by operando techniques to meet the market and societal demands is of great significance for their further development. This, however, needs to integrate the in situ characterizations into the mobile device like an electric vehicle, in which the instrument′s miniaturization is required. Currently, a handheld Raman spectrometer has been developed and applied in various fields, such as food safety, public security, environmental security, etc., to obtain information in a few seconds even with a trace amount of the Au nanoparticles decorated microchip is used as enhancement substrate. It shows broad prospects in the operando characterization of electrode materials, electrolytes, and interphases based on our group’s tens of years of research experience on Raman spectroscopy. Furthermore, optical fiber sensing methods also show appealing prospects for operando monitoring the strain, temperature, Oxygen concentration, etc. in a battery system. However, advances in operando monitoring the physical and chemical states of battery systems require the collaborative efforts of scientists from chemistry, physics, material, theory, and engineering [23,159]. Xiu-Mei Lin received her Master’s and Ph.D. degrees in Physical Chemistry from Xiamen University and Jena University. She then worked as a post-doctor at Helmholtz Institute Ulm for Electrochemical Energy Storage and Institute of Nanotechnology, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT) in Germany, during 2014-2018. She is an associate professor at the Minnan Normal University of Chemistry. Her research interests include electrochemical energy storage and conversion and the related reaction mechanism studies by various in situ techniques. Xin-Tao Yang received his Bachelor’s degree from Nanchang University, and he is a Master candidate in the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Xiamen University. His research interest focuses on designing, synthesizing, and applying advanced materials for Li/Na-ion batteries. Hao-Ning Chen is a Master candidate in the College of Energy at Xiamen University. His research interests mainly include the synthesis, characterization, and electrochemical performance tests of advanced Li/Na-ion battery materials. Yong-Liang Deng received his Bachelor’s degree from the Dalian University of Technology. He is a Master candidate in Materials and Chemical Engineering at Xiamen University. His research interests focus on in situ technique studies of advanced materials for Li/Na-ion batteries. Wen-Han Chen is a senior engineer in 21C Innovation Lab, Contemporary Amperex Technology Co. He received his Ph.D. in Material and Chemical Engineering from Xiamen University in 2021. His research interests focus on failure analysis and mechanism study for rechargeable lithium-ion and sodium-ion batteries. Jin-Chao Dong received his Ph.D. in Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2018. He has been an associate professor in the College of Energy at Xiamen University since 2020. His research interests include surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, the interfacial study of fuel cells, single crystal electrocatalysis, and energy storage and conversion. Yi-Min Wei received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2011. He currently serves as the Director of the Digital & Intelligence Research Center of 21C Innovation Laboratory of Contemporary Amperex Technology Co., Limited. He has more than ten years of experience in lithium/sodium-ion battery research and development at CATL. In recent years, he has led his team to deeply explore the field of frontier characterization, advanced sensing, nondestructive testing, multi-scale simulation modeling, intelligent battery design, etc., and is committed to building a digital and innovative research platform that connects the whole chain of fundamental research, application research, engineering, and product designs, and accelerates the innovation of lithium/sodium-ion batteries and the next generation of electrochemical energy storage systems. Jian-Feng Li is a full Professor of Chemistry at Xiamen University. He received his Bachelor’s degree in Chemistry from Zhejiang University in 2003 and his Ph.D. degree in Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2010. He worked as a post-doctor at the University of Bern and ETH Zurich in Switzerland from 2011 to 2014. Professor Li’s research interests include plasmonic core-shell nanostructures, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, electrochemical energy storage and conversion, surface catalysis, and rapid detection using portable Raman instruments. He has published more than 170-peer-reviewed papers with a total citation of over 15000, including Nature, Nature Energy, Nature Mater., Nature Nanotechnol., Nature Catal., Chem. Rev., etc. He is a Senior Editor of J. Phys. Chem. A/B/C.

coredata.dc:description: Energy storage is an ever-growing global concern due to increased energy needs and resource exhaustion. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have called increasing attention and achieved substantial progress in recent years owing to the abundance and even distribution of Na resources in the crust, and the predicted low cost of the technique. Nevertheless, SIBs still face challenges like lower energy density and inferior cycling stability compared to mature lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Enhancing the electrochemical performance of SIBs requires an in-deep and comprehensive understanding of the improvement strategies and the underlying reaction mechanism elucidated by in situ techniques. In this review, commonly applied in situ techniques, for instance, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), and their applications on the representative cathode and anode materials with selected samples are summarized. We discuss the merits and demerits of each type of material, strategies to enhance their electrochemical performance, and the applications of in situ characterizations of them during the de/sodiation process to reveal the underlying reaction mechanism for performance improvement. We aim to elucidate the composition/structure-performance relationship to provide guidelines for rational design and preparation of electrode materials toward high electrochemical performance.
